In the fall of 1933, Gutmann applied for a veteran's war pension which was granted. At this time, [[President of Germany|President]] [[Paul von Hindenberg]] had passed several verbal and written decrees allowing for the protection of Jewish war veterans from the rising tide of [[antisemitism]] in Germany. In 1935, after the passing of the [[Nuremberg Laws]], Gutmann lost his German citizenship and was formally discharged from the veteran rolls of the German Army. He still continued to receive a pension, however, possible due to Hitler's influence.<ref>According to the historian Werner Maser, Gutmann received, by Hitler's intervention, a pension from the Third Reich down to the end of the war.</ref>
